protocol_name: Detecting 16S rRNA Gene Fragments from a Metagenome to Assemble Full-Length 16S Sequences
protocol_name_html: Detecting 16S rRNA Gene Fragments from a Metagenome to Assemble Full-Length 16S Sequences
description:
Goal: Identify 16S rRNA gene metagenomic fragments and create assembled full-length 16S rRNA sequences from fragments.
Note 1 - As is this case with most bioinformatic processes, this is one of many possible methods, but has had successful results in the past
Note 2 - This method is best applied to sequences that have been subjected to quality control as in https://www.protocols.io/view/Basic-Illumina-Sequence-Quality-Control-d4e8td
before_start:
**There are many tools available for this process - this is one example that has been used effectively**
Required software:
IDBA-UD v. 1.1.1 - http://i.cs.hku.hk/~alse/hkubrg/projects/idba_ud/
Meta-RNA - http://weizhong-lab.ucsd.edu/meta_rna/
HMMER v3.1b2 - http://hmmer.janelia.org/
MetaRNA_to_FastQ.py - https://github.com/bjtully/BioData/tree/master/Various_Tools
Biopython - http://biopython.org/DIST/docs/tutorial/Tutorial.html#htoc4
EMIRGE - https://github.com/csmiller/EMIRGE
Cython
pysam
scipy/numpy
usearch (www.drive5.com/usearch/ -- tested with usearch version 6.0.203)
samtools (http://samtools.sourceforge.net/ -- tested with verison 0.1.18)
bowtie (http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/index.shtml -- tested with version 0.12.7 and 0.12.8)
protocol_affiliation: Center for Dark Energy Biosphere Investigations
affiliation: Center for Dark Energy Biosphere Investigations

components.data:
Convert quality trimmed FASTQ metagenomic sequences to a FASTA format
Assumes that sequences are paired-end
Perform conversion to FASTA.
fq2fa is available as part of IDBA-UD
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Convert quality trimmed FASTQ metagenomic sequences to a FASTA format
Assumes that sequences are paired-end
Perform conversion to FASTA.
fq2fa is available as part of IDBA-UD

source_data.name: fq2fa --merge --filter INFILE_NAME.R1.001_paired.fastq INFILE_NAME.R2.001_paired.fastq INFILE_NAME.001.merged.fasta
source_data.description:
--merge = interweave paired-end sequences in two separate FASTQ files, new file will have the format of R1, followed by R2, etc.
--filter = remove sequences containing Ns

components.data:
Detect small subunit (SSU) rRNA gene fragments using command-line based Meta-RNA

There have been several updates to this program - this example utilizes the version accessible following the link associated with the file 'readme_H3.txt (old file)' and 'Download here (old file)'
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Detect small subunit (SSU) rRNA gene fragments using command-line based Meta-RNA

There have been several updates to this program - this example utilizes the version accessible following the link associated with the file 'readme_H3.txt (old file)' and 'Download here (old file)'

source_data.name: rna_hmm3.py -i INFILE_NAME.001.merged.fasta -L /directory/location/of/HMM/files/rna_hmm3/HMM3/ -o OUTFILE_NAME.001_predictedRNAs -m ssu -e .0000000001 -p 36
source_data.description:
-L = provide the directory address of the downloaded, pre-computed HMM alignment models for both SSU and large subunit rRNA genes (part of the Meta-RNA tarball)
-o = set name of output file
-m = sets target as SSU fragments only
-e = E-value cutoff used by HMMER (1 x 10^-10)
-p = number of available CPUs

components.data:
Use the script MetaRNA_to_FastQ.py to use the output table created by Meta-RNA as a guide for trimming the original quality trimmed FASTQ files.

MetaRNA_to_FastQ.py is only confirmed to work with the version of Meta-RNA described above
Requires Biopython
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Use the script MetaRNA_to_FastQ.py to use the output table created by Meta-RNA as a guide for trimming the original quality trimmed FASTQ files.

MetaRNA_to_FastQ.py is only confirmed to work with the version of Meta-RNA described above
Requires Biopython

source_data.name: MetaRNA_to_FastQ.py -r OUTFILE_NAME.001_predictedRNAs -q INFILE_NAME.R1.001_paired.fastq -o OUTFILE_PREFIX1.001
source_data.description:
-r = Meta-RNA table output
-q = original FASTQ file searched by Meta-RNA
-o = a prefix for the outfile, the final file will have '.metagenome16S.fastq' as the suffix

components.data: Repeat Step 3 for R2 reads (and any other sets of reads from the same sample)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Repeat Step 3 for R2 reads (and any other sets of reads from the same sample)

components.data:
Combine output 'metagenome16S.fastq' files as desired

Options: (1) Pairs of 16S rRNA fragments, or (2) All 16S rRNA fragments from a single sample

components.data:
If using EMIRGE for the first time
EMIRGE requires a reference database. SILVA (Ref111) can be downloaded using the script provided with EMIRGE:
emirge_download_candidate_db.py
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
If using EMIRGE for the first time
EMIRGE requires a reference database. SILVA (Ref111) can be downloaded using the script provided with EMIRGE:
emirge_download_candidate_db.py

components.data:
If using EMIRGE for the first time
Reference database must be 'corrected' using the script provided with EMIRGE:
fix_nonstandard_chars.py
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
If using EMIRGE for the first time
Reference database must be 'corrected' using the script provided with EMIRGE:

If using EMIRGE for the first time
The Reference database must be indexed using bowtie

components.data: Assemble full-length 16S rRNA sequences using EMIRGE, using emirge_amplicon.py, as the input file is exclusively 16S rRNA fragments, not a full metagenome
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Assemble full-length 16S rRNA sequences using EMIRGE, using emirge_amplicon.py, as the input file is exclusively 16S rRNA fragments, not a full metagenome

source_data.name: emirge_amplicon.py ./emirgeWorkingDir -1 OUTFILE_NAME_all.metagenome16S.fastq -f /directory/location/of/EMIRGE/SSURef_111_candidate_db.fasta -b /directoy/location/of/EMIRGE/SSURef_111_candidate_db_btindex -l 260 -i 246 -s 88 -a 32 --phred33
source_data.description:
./emirgeWorkingDir = creates a working directory for EMIRGE command, if command needs to be re-run, must delete this directory OR change the directory name
-1 = input FASTQ file containing all metagenome16S.fastq sequences. It is possible to input paired-end reads files, requires addition of -2 option
-f = location of reference FASTA file
-b = location of reference FASTA bowtie index file
-l = max length of sequences
-i = insert size between sequences (required even if only using -1 option)
-s = standard deviation of insert sequence sizes
-a = number of available CPUs
--phred33 = utilizes 33 based Phred quality, standard output on current Illumina sequences

components.data:
Move to the 'emirgeWorkingDir' and create the final FASTA file using the script provided with EMIRGE:
emirge_rename_fasta.py
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Move to the 'emirgeWorkingDir' and create the final FASTA file using the script provided with EMIRGE:
emirge_rename_fasta.py

components.data:
Optional step: Assign taxonomy using mothur
Requires: Reference alignment for align.seqs and reference FASTA + taxonomy files for classify.seqs
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Optional step: Assign taxonomy using mothur
Requires: Reference alignment for align.seqs and reference FASTA + taxonomy files for classify.seqs

source_data.name:
align.seqs(fasta=INPUT.16S.fasta, reference=reference.alignment.fasta, flip=T, processors=64)
remove.seqs(accnos=INPUT.16S.flip.accnos, fasta=INPUT.16S.align)
classify.seqs(fasta=INPUT.16S.pick.align, template=reference.database.fasta, taxonomy=reference.database.tax, cutoff=80, iters=1000, processors=64)
source_data.description:
Run as 3 separate commands
Align to reference alignment
Remove sequences without alignments
Classify sequences using the reference database
flip = T - looks for matches in both forward and reverse directions
processors = available number of CPUs
cutoff = level cutoff for a taxonomic assignment
iters = number of comparisons performed to ensure correct assignment
